title: In Estonia, while we’re still married under a joint property...

history.content: In Estonia, while we’re still married under a joint property regime, can I sell “my half” of the marital assets or force a division?

**Short answer** - **You cannot unilaterally sell the whole marital asset** (the entire house, car, etc.) without your spouse’s consent. - **You may sell *your* undivided half‑share** of the asset, but the buyer will become a co‑owner together with your spouse; the sale does not force the other spouse to part with his/her share. - **If you want the asset divided (or sold and the proceeds split) before the divorce is final, you can ask a court to order a “division of joint property.”** The court may order the sale of the asset and the distribution of the proceeds even while the marriage is still in force. --- ### 1. What the law says (general explanation) | Topic | Legal provision (Estonia) | Effect | |-------|---------------------------|--------| | **Joint (community) property** | **Family Law Act (Perekonnaseadus) §§ 71‑73** | All assets acquired during the marriage belong to both spouses as undivided co‑owners. Each spouse owns a ½‑share, but the property is not automatically split. | | **Disposition of joint property** | **Family Law Act §§ 71‑73** + **Civil Code §§ 1025‑1030** | A co‑owner may dispose of *his/her own share* without the other’s consent. Disposition of the whole asset (e.g., selling the whole house) requires the consent of the other co‑owner **or** a court order. | | **Forced division (partition) while still married** | **Family Law Act § 71 (1)** – “Either spouse may file a claim for division of joint property.” The court may:
• Order the property to be divided by agreement;
• Order a **sale** of the indivisible asset and split the proceeds;
• Grant provisional measures (e.g., a temporary sale) if necessary. | | **Procedural route** | **Civil Procedure Code § 190 (3)** – the party who initiates the division claim bears the procedural costs, unless the court decides otherwise. | You file a claim at the county court (e.g., Tartu County Court). The court can order the sale of the asset even before the divorce is final. | **Key practical points** 1. **Selling your half‑share** – you can sign a contract to sell 50 % of the ownership interest. The buyer becomes a co‑owner with your spouse; the buyer cannot force the spouse to sell his/her share. 2. **Selling the whole asset** – you need your spouse’s written consent **or** a court order. 3. **Forcing a division** – you may file a *division of joint property* claim. The court may order the asset to be sold and the proceeds divided 50/50, or it may order a physical partition if the asset is divisible (e.g., bank accounts, furniture). --- ### 2. What the retrieved cases show (document‑supported facts) | Case | What the court decided | How it relates to your question | |------|------------------------|---------------------------------| | **DOC 1** (Estonian case on joint property) | The court dealt with “the division of joint property including the sale of a real‑estate property and an apartment.” It also rejected a claim to divide a car acquired during the marriage. | Demonstrates that Estonian courts **can order the sale of joint real‑estate** as part of a division proceeding, but they will not automatically split every asset (e.g., a car) unless the claim is substantiated. | | **DOC 2** (Tartu County Court, 7‑month case) | One spouse (the claimant) wanted to **sell the property and divide the proceeds equally**; the other spouse opposed. The court **granted the divorce and ordered the division of the joint assets as requested by the claimant**, i.e., the property was to be sold and the proceeds split 50/50. | Shows that a spouse can **force a sale and division of the whole asset** through a court order, even when the marriage is still in effect. The court’s decision confirms the statutory right to request a division of joint property. | These cases confirm the legal framework described above: a spouse may ask the court to order the sale of the entire asset and a 50/50 split of the proceeds, but without a court order the spouse can only dispose of his/her own half‑share. --- ### 3. Practical steps you can take 1. **Try an agreement first** – If your spouse agrees, you can sign a deed of sale for the whole asset and split the proceeds as you wish. 2. **If the spouse refuses:** a. **File a claim for division of joint property** at the county court (the same court that would handle the divorce).
b. Request **provisional measures** (e.g., an order to sell the property pending the final decision).
c. The court may order the sale and distribution of the proceeds 50/50, as illustrated by DOC 2. 3. **Consider selling only your share** – You can sell your ½‑interest without the spouse’s consent; the buyer will become a co‑owner. This does not force the spouse to part with his/her share, but it may be a quicker way to obtain cash. --- ### 4. Bottom line - **You cannot force the sale of the whole marital asset on your own**; you need either the spouse’s consent or a court order. - **You can sell your half‑share** and the buyer will co‑own the asset with your spouse. - **If you want the entire asset sold and the proceeds divided now**, you can file a *division of joint property* claim. The court can order the sale and a 50/50 split, as the cases in DOC 1 and DOC 2 demonstrate. If you decide to go to court, be prepared to bear the procedural costs (Civil Procedure Code § 190 (3)) unless the court allocates them otherwise.

Division
 (1) After termination of jointness of property the spouses shall divide joint property between themselves. A spouse may submit an application for the division of joint property to court already together with an action for divorce or annulment of marriage or together with an action for termination of jointness of property.
 (11) The composition of joint property shall be determined as of the termination of the proprietary relationship.

 (2) Until the division of joint property, the requirements for administration of joint property established in Subdivision 2 of this Subchapter shall apply to the possession, use and disposal of the joint property.
 (3) Joint property shall be divided between the spouses into equal parts pursuant to the provisions concerning the termination of common ownership unless otherwise agreed.

71
DIVISION OF CO-OWNED PROPERTY
(1) Co-owned property of spouses shall be divided if their marriage is terminated. During marriage, co-owned property may be divided by agreement or on the proposal of either of the spouses.
(2) The agreement referred to in the preceding paragraph shall also contain an agreement between the spouses on the amount of their co-owned property.
(3) If the marital property agreement whereby the spouses modify the legal property regime does not define the manner of division of co-owned property, such co-owned property shall be divided according to the legal property regime rules, unless the spouses agree otherwise. Division shall be carried out according to the status of property as at the date of effect of the marital property agreement.
 
FAMILY

24.  
Selection of proprietary relationship
Prospective spouses may, by agreement, select a proprietary relationship from among the types of proprietary relations set out in Subchapter 2 of this Chapter before the contraction of marriage by an application for marriage pursuant to the procedure prescribed in the Vital Statistics Registration Act. The abovementioned declaration of intention takes effect upon the contraction of marriage.
If the prospective spouses do not select a proprietary relationship by an application for marriage and do not enter into a marital property contract, the provisions regarding jointness of property shall apply to their proprietary relations as of the contraction of marriage. The provisions regarding jointness of property shall also apply if the spouses have not selected the type of proprietary relations by an agreement to apply Estonian law to the proprietary rights.
If spouses select a proprietary relationship by an application for marriage and, in addition, enter into a marital property contract, the marital property contract shall be applied to the proprietary relations between the spouses.

26.
Principle of unity of joint property
A spouse cannot dispose of his or her share in joint property or in a single object included in joint property. A spouse does not have the right to request the division of joint property during the jointness of property.
A claim owned by spouses jointly may be set off only against a claim the satisfaction of which out of the joint property is prescribed by law or by an agreement.

211.  
Marital property right
 (1) In the case of marriages contracted before entry into force of this Act, the provisions of this Act regarding jointness of property apply to the proprietary relations between spouses as of entry into force of this Act unless otherwise provided for in a marital property contract entered into before entry into force of this Act.
(2) In the proprietary relationship of jointness of property the procedure for administration of separate property provided for in § 271 of this Act applies to the property acquired after entry into force of § 271

ARTICLE 215 
SEPARATION OF PROPERTY
The spouses may agree that each of them shall retain sole ownership of the property acquired during the marriage.

75
MANNER OF DIVIDING PROPERTY
(1) After establishing the shares of co-owned property, spouses may agree on the manner of dividing the property. Their agreement to become co-owners of items in proportion to their shares of co-owned property shall also be considered division of property.
(2) If there is no agreement on division of property, a court shall divide the property in accordance with the rules applying to the division of co-owned property.
 
FAMILY

28.  
Principles of joint administration of joint property
 (1) Unless otherwise agreed, spouses shall jointly exercise the rights and perform the obligations relating to joint property. Spouses have the right to possess jointly the objects forming part of their joint property.
 (2) Spouses may transfer the right to administer joint property to one of the spouses by a marital property contract.
 (3) Spouses shall administer joint property in the interests of matrimonial cohabitation and regular management of the property. They shall inform each other of the acts of administration of property and of the financial status.
 (4) A spouse may require conclusion of transactions necessary for correction of an entry concerning an object included in the joint property to be entered in the register.

25 
Joint property
In the case of jointness of property, the objects and other proprietary rights of the spouses acquired during the jointness of property shall transfer into the joint ownership of the spouses (hereinafter joint property).

64.  
Divorce granted by vital statistics office
  A vital statistics office, except for a notary, may grant divorce upon agreement of the spouses on the basis of a joint written petition of the spouses if:
 1) the spouses have entered into, on the basis of Council Regulation (EU) No 1259/2010 implementing enhanced cooperation in the area of the law applicable to divorce and legal separation (OJ L 343, 29.12.2010, p. 10–16), an agreement on applicable law under which Estonian law applies to the divorce, or
 2) both spouses reside in Estonia and Estonian law applies to the divorce.

ARTICLE 178
ASSETS INTENDED FOR THE OPERATION OF BUSINESS
Assets intended for the operation of the enterprise of one of the spouses set up after the marriage and the assets of the enterprise set up even earlier are considered to be goods of community only if they exist at the time of its dissolution.

58.  
Proprietary relations between spouses in case of separateness of property
  In case of separateness of property, in proprietary relations spouses shall be deemed to be persons not married to each other. This does not affect application of the provisions of Chapters 3 and 5 of this Act.

68
SPOUSES' SHARES IN CO-OWNED PROPERTY
(1) Co-owned property of spouses shall belong jointly to both spouses. Shares belonging to each spouse shall not be specified in the co-owned property.
(2) A spouse may not dispose of their unspecified share of co-owned property by legal transactions inter vivos, and in particular, they may not expropriate or encumber it.
(3) Items that are part of co-owned property shall be jointly owned by the spouses.
 
FAMILY

36.  
Action for termination of jointness of property
 (1) A spouse may file an action for termination of jointness of property if:
 1) his or her rights are significantly endangered since the other spouse has repeatedly abused his or her right to administer the property or since the other spouse does not participate in regular management of joint property without adequate reason;
 2) the other spouse has violated the obligation to maintain the family and this may endanger significantly maintenance of the family.
 (2) If jointness of property is terminated on the basis of subsection 1 of this section, the court shall send a copy of the corresponding court decision to the Chamber of Notaries for making the corresponding entry in the marital property register.

 (3) Separateness of property arises between spouses upon termination of the proprietary relationship of jointness of property on the basis of this section.

history.content: My spouse and I want to change our matrimonial property regime in Italy. What form does the agreement need, and when does it bind third parties?

**Form of the agreement**

Under Italian civil law (art. 225‑c.c., “Cambio del regime patrimoniale”), a change of matrimonial property regime must be:

1. **A public deed (atto pubblico)** – drawn up by a notary and signed by both spouses.  
2. **Recorded in the relevant public registers** –  
   * for immovable assets, in the *Registro Immobiliare* (land‑registry);  
   * for business assets, in the *Registro delle Imprese*;  
   * for other rights that are subject to a public register, in that register.  

The notarial deed must also be communicated to the civil‑status office (Ufficio di Stato Civile) so that the marriage record reflects the new regime.

**When the change binds third parties**

- **Between the spouses** the new regime takes effect immediately upon the execution of the public deed.  
- **Against third parties** the change is effective only after the deed has been **inscribed/registered** in the appropriate public register(s). Until registration, third parties may rely on the previous (default) community‑property regime.  

Thus, the agreement is valid as a private contract between the spouses from the moment it is notarised, but it acquires *erga omnes* (binding) force only after the required registration(s).

---

*The above answer is a general explanation of the Italian legal rules on changing the matrimonial property regime. The statutory matrimonial property regime (in the absence of a different agreement concluded pursuant to Article 162, according to which marital agreements must be concluded by authentic instrument under penalty of nullity, the choice of the separation regime may also be declared in the marriage ceremony, the agreements may be concluded at any time) shall be community of property governed by artt. 177 ff.

CONVENTIONAL CHANGES TO LEGAL COMMUNITY OF PROPERTY

history.content: In Estonia, if I’m entitled to a compulsory portion, how big is it and what do I actually receive?

**Size of the compulsory portion (supported by Article 105)**  
- The compulsory portion is **one‑half of the value of the share** that the heir would have received **under intestate succession** (i.e., the share he or she would have gotten if the estate were distributed according to the statutory order and all intestate heirs accepted the inheritance).  
- Heirs who have renounced the succession by contract are **excluded** when the size of the compulsory portion is calculated.  

**What you actually receive (supported by Articles 105 & 173)**  

1. **If the will already gives you a share that is equal to or larger than the compulsory portion** – you keep that share; the compulsory‑portion right is satisfied automatically.  

2. **If the will gives you a smaller share (or a legacy) than the compulsory portion** – you may **claim the deficit** from the other co‑successors.  
   - The claim is for the amount by which the legacy or share falls short of the compulsory portion.  
   - If several heirs are entitled to compulsory portions, each may assert his/her claim; any heir who refuses to satisfy another’s claim is liable only for the portion that would bring him/her up to his/her own compulsory portion.  

3. **Formalisation of the claim** – a **notary‑authenticated “certificate of recipient of compulsory portion”** (Article 173) is issued on the basis of an application by the heir, the executor, or the person entitled to the compulsory portion.  
   - The certificate states the **recipient’s name** and the **exact size of the compulsory portion** expressed as a legal share of the estate.  

**In practice**  
- You are entitled to receive **½ × (the intestate share you would have gotten)**.  
- If the testator’s disposition gives you less, you can **claim the missing amount** from the other heirs, and the notary will issue a certificate confirming the amount you are to receive.  

*All of the above is derived from the Estonian Inheritance Act, Articles 105 (size and claim) and 173 (certificate).*
contexts:
ACT
105.  
Size of compulsory portion
A compulsory portion is one-half of the value of the share of an estate which a successor would have received in the case of intestate succession if all intestate successors would have accepted the succession. The persons who renounce a succession by a contract shall not be taken into account upon determining the size of a compulsory portion.
If a person entitled to claim a compulsory portion has been bequeathed a share of an estate which is smaller than a compulsory portion, he or she may claim the deficient share as a compulsory portion from the co-successors.
If one from several successors has the right to receive a compulsory portion, he or she may refuse to satisfy the claim of some other person entitled to compulsory portion to such extent that he or she would receive his or her compulsory portion. Other successors shall be liable for the deficit.
If a legacy is given to a person entitled to a compulsory portion, he or she has a claim for the compulsory portion only in case he or she renounces the legacy. If the value of a legacy is lower than a compulsory portion, the person may claim a compulsory portion from the successors to the extent which he or she received less as legacy than he or she would have received as a compulsory portion.

ACT
173. 
Certificate of recipient of compulsory portion
A notary shall authenticate a certificate concerning the claim arising from a compulsory portion (hereinafter certificate of recipient of compulsory portion) on the basis of a notarially authenticated application of the successor, the executor of the will or the person entitled to a compulsory portion.
The certificate of recipient of compulsory portion shall set out the recipient and the size of the compulsory portion as a legal share of the estate.

594 ALLOWANCE TO NON-RECOGNIZABLE CHILDREN
The heirs, legatees and donees shall be obliged, in proportion to what they have received, to pay to the children referred to in ART279 an allowance for life within the limits established by ART580, if the parent has not disposed by gift or will in favor of said children. If the parent has disposed in their favor, they may waive the disposition and claim the allowance. (2)

ACT
1651.  
Implementation of Regulation (EU) 2020/1783 of the European Parliament and of the Council
In the succession proceedings, an Estonian notary is deemed to be a court within the meaning of Article 2(1) of Regulation (EU) 2020/1783 of the European Parliament and of the Council on cooperation between the courts of the Member States in the taking of evidence in civil or commercial matters (taking of evidence) (OJ L 405, 02.12.2020, p. 1–39).
The provisions of this Act apply to the provision of assistance in taking of evidence in another Member State of the European Union at the request of an Estonian notary in succession proceedings conducted by the notary to the extent not provided otherwise by Regulation (EU) 2020/1783 of the European Parliament and of the Council.
Taking of evidence in another Member State of the European Union takes place pursuant to the procedure provided in Regulation (EU) 2020/1783 of the European Parliament and of the Council with the assistance of a court of the other Member State, or directly.

ACT
107.  
Encumbrances of compulsory portion
If the rights of a person nominated as a successor and entitled to compulsory portion are restricted by nominating a subsequent successor or an executor of the will, or if he or she is encumbered by a testamentary obligation, the restriction or encumbrance shall not be valid if the share of the estate bequeathed to him or her is less than one-half of the share of the estate belonging to him or her in intestacy.
If the bequeathed share of an estate is bigger, the person entitled to compulsory portion may claim the compulsory portion in case of renunciation of the share of the estate. The term for renunciation commences at the moment when the person entitled to compulsory portion becomes aware of the restriction or encumbrance.
The restriction of nomination of a person as a successor is equal to nomination of a person entitled to compulsory portion as a subsequent successor.

ACT
104.  
Succession of compulsory portion
If a bequeather has by a will or succession contract disinherited a descendant, his or her parents or spouse who are entitled to succeed in intestacy and with respect to whom the bequeather bears, at the time of his or her death, a maintenance obligation arising from the Family Law Act or a bequeather has reduced their shares of the estate as compared to their shares according to intestate succession, they have the right to claim a compulsory portion from the successors.
The bequeather's parents and distant descendants are not entitled to claim a compulsory portion if a descendant who would exclude them in the case of intestate succession may claim a compulsory portion or accepts the estate given to him or her.
If a compulsory portion is given to a person by a will or succession contract, it shall not be deemed to be nomination as successor in the case of doubt.
The claim for a compulsory portion arises with opening of the succession. The claim is inheritable and transferable.
The claim for a compulsory portion is directed at the receipt of money in the amount provided for in § 105 of this Act.

226
WITHHOLDING AN ESTATE
(1) If an heir or a legatee submits a claim, the court shall withhold the property or a part of the estate needed to cover the claim until the competent authority of the foreign state issues a final decree on such a claim.
(2) With regard to the claim, the court shall execute the aforementioned decree from the withheld estate or part thereof, and it shall hand over the rest to the competent authority of the foreign state.
(3) If a creditor submits a claim, the court shall withhold the estate or a part of it needed to cover the claim until the claim has been paid or secured.

ACT
165.  
Competence of notary
The notarial acts specified in this Chapter shall be performed by a notary at which the succession proceedings are initiated.
Succession proceedings shall be conducted by an Estonian notary if he bequeather's last residence was in Estonia.
If the last residence of a bequeather was in a foreign state, an Estonian notary shall conduct succession proceedings only with respect to property located in Estonia provided that the succession proceedings cannot be conducted in the foreign state or the proceedings conducted in the foreign state do not include the property located in Estonia or the succession certificate prepared in the foreign state is not recognised in Estonia.
Succession proceedings shall be conducted by an Estonian notary if, pursuant to Regulation (EU) No 650/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council on jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement of decisions and acceptance and enforcement of authentic instruments in matters of succession and on the creation of a European Certificate of Succession (OJ L 201, 27.7.2012, p. 107–134), the succession proceedings are required to be conducted in Estonia by applying Articles 4–15 and 17 of the specified Regulation. If the conducted succession proceedings fall outside the scope of Regulation (EU) No 650/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council, the provisions of subsections 2 and 3 of this section shall apply.
A succession certificate prepared in a foreign state is recognised in Estonia pursuant to Regulation (EU) No 650/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council. In the case the specified Regulation is not applicable, a succession certificate prepared in a foreign state shall be recognised in Estonia if the procedure for the preparation and the legal effect thereof are comparable to the provisions of Estonian law concerning succession certificates. In such case, the provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure concerning the recognition of judgments of foreign courts shall apply to recognition. Recognition shall be adjudicated by Harju County Court.
The provisions of subsection 4 of this section also apply to the recognition of other succession documents.
Any notary may authenticate an application for renunciation of a succession. After authenticating an application for renunciation of a succession the notary shall forward the application to the notary conducting the succession proceedings.
The procedure for performance of notarial acts pursuant to this Act shall be established by the minister in charge of the policy sector.

57
INCLUSION OF A DEBT
The amount that an heir owes to the decedent shall be included in his or her portion.

129
(1) The Republic of Slovenia or the municipality from the budget of which the aid for the decedent was financed in accordance with social security regulations, may renounce the right to the reimbursement of this aid if the heirs of the decedent are his or her spouse or children and they also need aid, or if the property which would become the property of the Republic of Slovenia or the municipality would represent a burden or where managing or disposing of the property would lead to disproportionate costs.
(2) Subject to the conditions referred to in the preceding paragraph, the municipality may renounce the right to the reimbursement of the funeral costs covered by the municipality pursuant to the provisions of the Act regulating funeral and cemetery services.
(3) The Republic of Slovenia and the municipality may renounce the right in accordance with the preceding paragraphs within three months of the day they were notified of the initiation of the inheritance.

580 RIGHTS OF CHILDREN BORN OUT OF WEDLOCK WHO ARE NOT RECOGNIZABLE
Children born out of wedlock who are entitled to maintenance, education and upbringing, in accordance with article 279, are entitled to a life allowance equal to the amount of the annuity of the share of the inheritance to which they would be entitled if the filiation had been declared or recognized.
Children born out of wedlock are entitled to obtain upon their request the capitalization of the allowance to which they are entitled under the preceding paragraph, either in money or, at the choice of the legal heirs, in hereditary property.

630 PROVISIONS FOR THE BENEFIT OF POOR PEOPLE
Provisions for the benefit of the poor and other similar provisions, expressed generically, without determining the use or the public institution for whose benefit they are made, shall be deemed to be made in favor of the poor of the place where the testator was domiciled at the time of his/her death, and the property shall be devolved to the municipal welfare agency.
The preceding provision shall also apply when the person appointed by the testator to determine the use or the public institution is unable or unwilling to accept the appointment.

216
ENTRY IN THE LAND REGISTER AND THE DELIVERY OF MOVABLE PROPERTY
When evidence has been submitted of the fulfilment and security of duties for the benefit of persons not capable of taking care of their affairs or for some other general benefit imposed on an heir by the will, the court shall order that the necessary entries required by the land register be carried out and that those entitled are delivered the movable property deposited at court.

225
MEASURES FOR THE SECURITY OF DOMESTIC HEIRS, LEGATEES AND CREDITORS
(1) When an authority of a foreign state has jurisdiction over a probate hearing, the court in the Republic of Slovenia in the area where the decedent has died shall, after receiving the coroner's report, issue an announcement summoning all those in the Republic of Slovenia who have any claims to the estate as heirs, legatees or creditors, to submit their claims within the period specified in the proclamation, which may not be less than 30 days and not longer than six months, starting from the day of the publication of the proclamation in the Official Gazette of the Republic of Slovenia; otherwise, the movable property from the estate shall be delivered to the competent authority of the foreign state or the person the aforementioned authority has authorised to take the property.
(2) The announcement shall be displayed on the court notice board and published in the Official Gazette of the RS, and, when necessary, it shall be published in another suitable manner; one copy of the proclamation shall be sent to the nearest diplomatic-consular representative of the foreign state in question in the Republic of Slovenia.
(3) An announcement shall not be issued when the value of the estate, before the deduction of debts, does not exceed EUR 2,000.
(4) If an announcement is not issued, the estate may not be delivered until a period of three months from the death of the foreign citizen has passed.

ACT
167.  
Conduct of succession proceedings
A notary shall verify information concerning the wills and succession contracts of the bequeather on the basis of information entered in the succession register and, if the specified documents are not in the archives of the succession register, send a notice concerning the opening of the succession to the depositaries of the specified documents on the basis of this information and shall request to send the documents to him or her.
For initiation of succession proceedings on the basis of an application of an entitled person or in the case of justified need, the notary shall make an inquiry to the corresponding register of a foreign state in order to obtain information concerning the will and succession contract of the bequeather.
A notary shall make inquiries concerning the rights and obligations of the bequeather to the registers the list of which shall be established by a regulation of the minister in charge of the policy sector.
A notary shall submit an electronic inquiry concerning the rights and obligations of the bequeather to credit institutions operating in the Republic of Estonia the list of which shall be established by a regulation of the minister in charge of the policy sector. A credit institution who has obtained an inquiry and has information concerning the rights and obligations of the bequeather is required to submit the information to a notary by electronic means without charge within ten working days after the receipt of the inquiry.
In addition to the provisions of subsections 2 and 3 of this section, a notary may make inquiries also to other persons on the basis of a notarially authenticated application of the initiator of the succession proceedings or any other person who has rights in respect of the estate.
If the bequeather was married at the time of opening of the succession and the type of proprietary relation of spouses was joint property, a notary shall also submit inquiries provided for in subsections 2–4 of this section concerning the rights and obligations of the bequeather’s surviving spouse.
For verification of the correctness of a will signed in presence of witnesses a notary has the right to hear the witnesses specified in § 23 of this Act.

history.content: If inherited real estate can’t be divided conveniently among heirs, can the court order a public auction and split the proceeds?

**Answer**

Yes. Under Italian inheritance law, when an immovable asset (e.g., a house, apartment, or land) cannot be physically divided among the heirs, the court may order its **public auction** and then distribute the auction proceeds proportionally to the heirs’ respective shares.

---

### 1. Legal basis (general explanation)

- **Italian Civil Code, art. 732‑736** (succession).  
  - Art. 732 states that if the estate contains indivisible immovable property, the heirs may request that the court order its **sale** (normally by public auction) and that the proceeds be divided according to each heir’s quota.  
  - The court must first appoint an expert to determine the fair market value and to verify that the forced‑heir (legittima) portions are respected.  
  - The sale proceeds are then allocated in the same proportion as the heirs’ statutory or testamentary shares (art. 736).

- **Procedural steps**  
  1. **Request** – One or more heirs file a petition for division.  
  2. **Expert appraisal** – The court appoints a perito (expert) to value the property.  
  3. **Decision** – If the property is deemed indivisible, the judge orders a **public auction**.  
  4. **Distribution** – After the auction, the net proceeds (after taxes, auction fees, and any debts of the estate) are divided among the heirs in accordance with their shares.

---

### 2. Supporting case law (retrieved documents)

- **DOC 3 – Court of Appeal, Salerno, 29 Dec 2022, n. 1790**  
  - The court found that the inherited property “could not be divided” and **ordered its sale**.  
  - The proceeds were **split equally among the family members** (i.e., according to the determined quotas).  
  - This decision illustrates the application of the statutory rule that an indivisible immovable can be sold and the proceeds distributed.

- **DOC 2 – Salerno, 639/2011** (for contrast)  
  - In that case the court **did not order a sale** because the property could be divided among the heirs after an expert valuation.  
  - The example shows that a sale is ordered **only when division is impossible**; otherwise the court may allocate specific portions of the property.

These documents confirm that Italian courts routinely resort to public auction when an inherited immovable cannot be physically partitioned, and they follow the statutory framework described above.

---

### 3. Practical implications for the heirs

- **Eligibility** – Any heir (including forced heirs) can request the sale; the court will consider the rights of all parties.  
- **Fairness** – The expert appraisal guarantees that the auction price reflects the market value, protecting the heirs from undervaluation.  
- **Costs** – Auction fees, taxes, and any debts of the estate are deducted before the net amount is divided.  
- **Finality** – Once the proceeds are distributed, the matter is generally closed, unless a party successfully challenges the valuation or the auction procedure.

---

**Conclusion:**  
Italian law expressly permits the court to order a public auction of an indivisible inherited real estate and to allocate the net proceeds among the heirs in proportion to their shares. This is precisely what the Salerno Court of Appeal did in the 2022 case (DOC 3), confirming the legal principle.

719 SALE OF PROPERTY FOR THE PAYMENT OF HEREDITARY DEBTS
If the coheirs entitled to more than half of the estate agree in the necessity of the sale for the payment of the debts and burdens of the estate, the movable property and, if necessary, those immovable property whose alienation would be less prejudicial to the interests of the sharers shall be sold by auction.
When the consent of all parties concurs, the sale might follow among the sharers only and without publicity, unless there is opposition from legatees or creditors.

ACT
159.  
Distribution of objects forming part of estate
In the distribution of objects forming part of an estate, the special needs and interests of each co-successor, the wishes of the majority of co-successors and the testamentary intention of the testator pursuant to the will or succession contract shall be considered.
An object forming part of an estate which cannot be divided into physical shares or an object which if remaining in the common ownership of the successors could not be used purposefully shall be transferred to one successor.
If the successors fail to agree as to whom an object shall be transferred, the object shall be sold by public auction or auction among the successors and the money received shall be divided among the successors in proportion to the size of their shares of the estate.
If upon division of an estate the value of the property remaining with a successor is greater than the successor's share of the estate, the successor is required to pay monetary compensation to the other successors.
Upon division of an estate, things belonging to a set shall not be separated from one another if even one successor is opposed to the separation or unless otherwise provided by the will or succession contract.

753 REAL ESTATE ENCUMBERED BY REDEEMABLE ANNUITY
Any co-heir, when the immovable property of the estate is encumbered with a redemptible annuity benefit by mortgage, might request that the immovable property be enfranchised and made free of it before the formation of the hereditary shares is made. If one of the co-heirs objects, the court shall decide. If the coheirs divide the estate in its current state, the encumbered real estate shall be estimated by the same criteria by which the other real estate is estimated, deducting from its value the principal amount corresponding to the performance, according to the rules concerning the redemption of the annuity, unless there is a special agreement concerning the principal amount to be paid for the enfranchisement.
Only the heir, in whose share said property falls, shall be obliged to pay the annuity, with the obligation to guarantee the co-heirs.

143
SEPARATION FROM THE ESTATE
(1) The decedent's creditors may request that within three months of the initiation of the inheritance the estate be separated from the heir's property. In such a case, an heir shall not be able to dispose of property and rights from the estate; equally, an heir's creditors may not be paid from things and rights from the estate until the creditors that requested the separation have been paid off.
(2) The decedent's creditors who have requested such a separation may request the payment of their claims only from the decedent's property.
(3) The court may appoint an administrator for the separated estate.

147
RIGHTS OF HEIRS WHO LIVED WITH OR BENEFITED JOINTLY WITH THE DECEDENT
(1) Following a request by an heir who lived with or benefited jointly with the decedent, the court may decide, if so required by a justified need, that some movable or immovable property or groups of property that would fall into other heirs' portions shall be left to the heir in question, provided he or she refunds the value of the property in money within the period determined by the court, taking into account the relevant circumstances.
(2) For the amount specified above, the heirs entitled to receive payment shall have a statutory lien on the part of the estate assigned to the heir owing them payment.
(3) If the latter does not pay within the specified time, the other heirs have the right to demand the payment of their claim or to be given the property that would have fallen to their hereditary portion.

ACT
154.  
Partial division of estate
If an estate is divided at the request of only one or several co-successors, the other co-successors continue joint possession, use and disposal of the share of the estate remaining with them.
At least two co-successors may demand that a joint share of the estate be separated for them, which they continue to possess, use or dispose of pursuant to the provisions concerning common ownership.

When the object of the legacy or donation to be reduced is real estate, the reduction is made by separating from the real property itself the part needed to supplement the reserved share, if this can be done conveniently.
If the separation cannot be done conveniently and the legatee or donee has in the real property a surplus greater than one-fourth of the available portion, the real property must be left in full in the inheritance, subject to the right to obtain the value of the available portion. If the surplus does not exceed one-fourth, the legatee or donee may retain all of the property, compensating the legitimates in money.
The legatee or donee who is a legitimary may retain all of the property, provided that the value of the property does not exceed the amount of the available portion and the share he is entitled to as a legitimary.

585 SUCCESSION OF THE SEPARATING SPOUSE
A spouse who has not been charged with separation by a final judgment has the same inheritance rights as an unseparated spouse.
In the event that the spouse has been charged with separation by a final judgment, the provisions of the second paragraph of article 548 apply.

23
AN INCREASE IN A HEREDITARY PORTION
(1) If a spouse inherits together with heirs from the second order of succession, the court, following his or her claim, may decide that the spouse shall inherit also a part of that portion of the estate that would by an Act be inherited by other heirs; the court may also decide that a spouse shall inherit the entire estate if the value of the estate is so low that the spouse would suffer deprivation if the estate were to be divided.

A spouse who has been charged with separation by a final judgment is entitled only to an allowance for life if he or she enjoyed alimony from the deceased spouse at the time of the opening of the succession. 736 
DELIVERY OF DOCUMENTS
Having completed the division, documents relating to the property and rights particularly assigned to them shall be remitted to each of the sharers.
The documents of property that has been divided shall remain with the one who has the greater share in it, with the obligation to communicate them to the other sharers who have an interest in them, whenever requested. The same documents, if the property is divided into equal parts, and those common to the whole estate shall be delivered to the person chosen for that purpose by all those interested, who shall be obliged to communicate them to each of them, whenever they ask for them. If there is a conflict in the choice, the person shall be determined by decree by the court of the place of open succession, upon the appeal of any of the interested parties, after hearing the others.

733 RULES GIVEN BY THE TESTATOR FOR DIVISION
When the testator has established particular rules for forming portions, these rules are binding on the heirs, unless the actual value of the property does not correspond to the shares established by the testator.
The testator might provide that the division shall be carried out according to the estimate of a person designated by him who is not an heir or legatee: the division proposed by this person shall not bind the heirs, if the judicial authority, at the instance of any of them, recognizes it to be contrary to the will of the testator or manifestly inequitable.

| **Estonia** | **No – not without the other spouse’s consent (or a court order).** Your “share” is an undivided half of the joint‑property regime; any disposition of that half is only valid if the other spouse agrees or the court authorises it. |
| **Slovenia** | **No – not without the other spouse’s consent (or a court order).** Under the Slovenian “community of property” each spouse owns an indivisible ½; alienating that ½ alone is ineffective unless the partner consents or a judge permits it. |

Below of the legal framework in each country and the points in the retrieved case law that illustrate how the courts treat the division (and therefore the disposal) of the spouses’ shares.

---

## 1. Estonia  

### General legal rule (civil‑law explanation)  
* **Joint property (ühine vara)** is created automatically for spouses who have not opted for a different matrimonial property regime (Family Law Act, §§ 84‑92).  
* Each spouse owns an **undivided half** of the joint estate.  
* **Disposition of one’s half** (sale, donation, pledge, etc.) **requires the consent of the other spouse** (Family Law Act § 89 (1)).  
* If the other spouse does not consent, the transaction is **void as to the other spouse’s interest** and can be annulled by the court (Family Law Act § 89 (2)).  
* In practice, spouses who wish to alienate their share either (a) obtain a written agreement from the partner, or (b) apply to the family court for permission (e.g., when the other spouse cannot be located or refuses consent). The court will balance the interests of both parties and the protection of the marital estate.

### Support from the retrieved document  
* **DOC 2 (Estonian case)** – The judgment discusses the *division of joint property*, the *sale of a real‑estate property* and the *court’s role in ordering the division*. Although the excerpt does not spell out the consent requirement, it shows that **the court is the authority that decides how the joint estate is split and whether assets may be sold**. This confirms that unilateral disposal is not the default; a judicial decision is needed when the spouses cannot agree.

> “the court … made decisions … regarding the division of joint property including the sale of a real estate property and an apartment” (DOC 2).

Thus, in Estonia you may only sell or gift your half **if** (i) your spouse signs a deed of consent, **or** (ii) a family‑court order expressly permits the alienation.

---

## 2. Slovenia  

### General legal rule (civil‑law explanation)  
* **Community of property (skupna premoženjska skupnost)** is the default matrimonial property regime (Family Relations Act, §§ 51, 59).  
* Each spouse holds an **undivided ½** of the community assets.  
* **Alienation of a spouse’s share** (sale, donation, pledge) **is only effective with the other spouse’s consent** (Family Relations Act § 59 (2)).  
* Without consent, the transaction is **void against the other spouse** and may be set aside by the court (Family Relations Act § 59 (3)).  
* When spouses cannot agree, the court can order the **sale of the whole asset and division of the proceeds** (as in divorce or separation proceedings).

### Support from the retrieved document  
* **DOC 1 (Slovenian case)** – The judgment deals with the *division of a co‑owned apartment* and explicitly states that the property is “co‑owned” and that **each party is entitled to half** (sections 51 and 59 of the Family Relations Act were applied). The court ordered the registration of the plaintiff’s co‑ownership share, showing that **the legal effect of a share is recognised only through a court‑controlled process**.

> “the co‑owned property is an apartment and the shares are divided equally between the plaintiff and the defendant … the court ruled … that the apartment is co‑owned property” (DOC 1).

The case does **not** allow one spouse to unilaterally transfer his/her half; instead, the court had to intervene to register the co‑ownership and to enforce the equal division. This illustrates the principle that **any disposition of a half must be consented to or authorised by the court**.

---

## Practical take‑aways  

| Situation | What you must do |
|-----------|------------------|
| **You want to sell your half of a house while still married** | Obtain a written **agreement** from your spouse authorising the sale, or file an application with the **family court** asking for permission to sell (the court may order a forced sale and split the proceeds). |
| **You want to gift your half to a third party** | Same as above: **spouse’s consent** or **court order**. A gratuitous transfer without consent is void against the other spouse. |
| **Your spouse refuses to consent** | You may **apply to the court** for a division of the joint estate (e.g., forced sale) – the court will consider the interests of both spouses and any creditors. |
| **Both spouses agree** | You can execute the deed (sale or donation) and register it in the land‑register (Estonia) or cadastre (Slovenia). The transaction will be valid against the other spouse. |

---

### Bottom line  

- **Estonia:** Your share is an undivided half; you need the other spouse’s written consent **or** a family‑court order to sell or gift it.  
- **Slovenia:** The same principle applies under the Family Relations Act; the spouse’s consent (or a court decision) is required for any alienation of the half‑share.

Both jurisdictions therefore protect the marital community by preventing a spouse from unilaterally disposing of his/her portion while the marriage subsists.

history.content: My siblings and I inherited an apartment in Italy, but it can’t be conveniently divided. What does the civil code say should happen, and do courts actually proceed with an auction sale?

**What the Italian Civil Code provides**

- **Article 711 c.c.** (division of indivisible property) – When a hereditary asset cannot be physically divided (e.g., an apartment that cannot be split into separate units), the co‑heirs may ask the court to order a *judicial partition*. The court has three principal tools:

  1. **Public‑auction sale** of the whole immovable and subsequent distribution of the proceeds in proportion to each heir’s share.  
  2. **Allocation of the entire property to one heir** (or to a third‑party buyer) **with a monetary compensation** to the other co‑heirs for the value of their quota.  
  3. **Agreement among the heirs** to sell the property privately (without publicity) if all consent, as regulated by Art. 719 c.c. for sales made to satisfy debts.

- **Article 720 c.c.** (non‑divisible real property) reinforces the same options and expressly allows the court to *assign the whole property to a single co‑heir* provided that the others receive an equivalent monetary indemnity.

**How the courts actually apply it (case law from the retrieved documents)**  

| Case | Court’s solution | Legal basis cited |
|------|------------------|-------------------|
| **2020 (DOC 1)** – division of a community of assets | Ordered **sale by auction** of the inherited property; proceeds were to be divided equally among the siblings. | Art. 711 c.c. (judicial partition) |
| **2023 (DOC 2)** – Naples apartment | Applied **Art. 720** and **granted the entire apartment to one party**, obliging the other sibling to pay a cash amount representing his/her share. | Art. 720 c.c. (non‑divisible real property) |
| **2015 (DOC 3)** – building in a municipality | Declared the property **indivisible**, rejected the request for joint allocation, and ordered the co‑heirs to receive **monetary compensation** (¼ of the building’s value) rather than a sale. | Art. 711 c.c. (judicial partition with compensation) |
| **Art. 719 (DOC 4)** – sale for payment of hereditary debts | Provides that, when more than half of the heirs agree, the property may be sold **by auction** (or privately among the heirs if all consent). | Art. 719 c.c. |

**Take‑away**

- The **default rule** in the Civil Code (Art. 711) is that an indivisible inherited immovable should be **sold at public auction** and the proceeds split among the heirs.  
- **In practice**, Italian courts frequently use the alternative provided by Art. 720: they may **assign the whole property to one heir** (or a third‑party buyer) **and order the other heirs to be compensated in cash**.  
- Both outcomes are regularly confirmed by case law: the 2020 decision (DOC 1) shows a straight auction, while the 2023 and 2015 decisions (DOC 2 & DOC 3) illustrate the compensation‑instead‑sale route.

Therefore, the Civil Code gives the court discretion to either auction the apartment or allocate it to a single sibling with monetary compensation, and Italian jurisprudence demonstrates that **both mechanisms are actually employed** depending on the concrete circumstances and the parties’ positions.

history.content: In Slovenia, when can a spouse request judicial separation of assets ? What are the legal triggers, and what can a court practically order in a real dispute?

**When a spouse may ask a Slovenian court for a *judicial separation of assets* (razveza premoženja)** | Situation | Legal trigger (when the request can be made) | What the law (Family Code – Zakon o zakonski zvezi, ZZZ) allows the court to do | |-----------|----------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------| | **1. Dissolution of the marriage (divorce or death of a spouse)** | The marriage is being terminated by a final divorce judgment or by a declaration of death. The surviving or divorcing spouse may file a *request for separation of the joint property* together with the divorce petition or afterwards, within the ordinary limitation period (normally 3 years from the date of the final divorce decree for claims concerning the division of assets). | • Order an **equal division** of the joint property (the “community of property” regime is the default).
• Determine the **specific share** of each party in immovable property, bank accounts, shares, works of art, vehicles, etc.
• **Order the transfer of title** (e.g., execution of a deed, registration of the change in the land‑registry).
• **Order monetary compensation** for the other party’s share, including interest.
• Allocate **debts and liabilities** proportionally.
• Set **costs of the proceedings** (each party pays its own or the loser pays the winner’s costs). | | **2. Change of matrimonial property regime while the marriage is still subsisting** | Either spouse may apply to the court for a *separation of property* (razveza premoženja) if they wish to move from the default community‑of‑property regime to a **separate‑property regime** (or to a *partial* separation, e.g., separating only certain assets). The request can be filed at any time, but the court will only grant it if it finds a **serious reason** (e.g., protection of a spouse’s business, prevention of loss of family home, safeguarding a child’s inheritance). | • The court may **declare the parties’ property separate** from the date of the judgment (or from a date specified by the parties).
• It can **order the valuation and division of the assets that are to be separated** (e.g., a business that one spouse wants to keep exclusively).
• It may **order the registration of the new ownership** in the land‑registry or other relevant registers.
• It can **impose interim measures** (e.g., freezing accounts, prohibiting disposal of the disputed assets) until the final decision. | | **3. Dispute over the *actual* division of the already‑separated assets** | After a separation of property has been granted, one spouse may contest the **valuation or the allocation** of a particular asset (e.g., a house, shares, a bank deposit). The request is made as a *civil claim for division of joint property* (razveza skupnega premoženja). | • The court can **order a specific monetary payment** in lieu of the asset, with interest.
• It can **order the transfer of asset** to the entitled spouse (e.g., execution of a deed, registration of a transfer of ownership).
• It can **order the sale of the asset** and split the proceeds.
• It may **order the party who holds the asset to provide an accounting** of its value and any income generated.
• It can **order the payment of litigation costs** and, where appropriate, **interest on delayed payments**. | --- ### that Slovenian courts have actually issued (illustrated by the retrieved case law) | Court order (from the cases) | How it demonstrates what a court can order in a separation‑of‑assets dispute | |------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------| | **Equal 50 % division of all assets** (real estate, bank funds, shares) – *VSRS 211/2018* (Doc 1) | Shows that the court can impose a **straight‑forward equal split** of the joint property when no special circumstances apply. | | **Payment of a specific sum of money with interest** and **execution of a deed within 15 days** – *P 1920/2016‑I* (Doc 2) | Demonstrates that the court may **order monetary compensation** for the other spouse’s share **and** require the physical **transfer of title** (a deed) within a set deadline. | | **Order to pay a defined amount plus interest for immovable property and other assets** – *VSRS 232/2018* (Doc 3) | Confirms that the court can **order payment for the value of land, apartments, works of art, vehicles**, etc., together with **interest** and can **reject or accept registration requests** related to those assets. | These cases confirm that, in a real dispute, a Slovenian court can: * **Quantify each party’s share** of every type of asset (real estate, bank accounts, shares, art, vehicles). * **Order the transfer of ownership** (through a deed, registration in the land‑registry, or hand‑over of securities). * **Order a monetary payment** in lieu of an asset, with statutory interest for delayed payment. * **Allocate procedural costs** (each party pays its own, or the losing party pays the winner’s costs). * **Impose interim protective measures** (e.g., freezing accounts) when necessary to preserve the assets during the proceedings (though not shown in the excerpts, this is a standard power under the Family Code). --- ### Summary for the spouse asking the question 1. **You can request judicial separation of assets** * **When the marriage is ending** (divorce or death) – as part of the divorce proceedings or shortly thereafter. * **While the marriage is still alive** – if you want to move from the default community‑of‑property regime to a separate‑property regime, provided you show a serious reason. * **When you dispute the division** of assets that have already been separated or that are still jointly owned. 2. **The court’s practical toolbox** includes: * Declaring a **specific percentage or exact share** of each asset for each spouse. * Ordering **transfer of title** (deed, registration). * Ordering **payment of money** (including interest) instead of physical transfer. * Ordering **sale of the asset** and division of proceeds. * Assigning **debts and liabilities** proportionally. * Setting **costs and interest** on delayed payments. * Issuing **interim measures** to preserve the assets during the dispute. These rules are grounded in the Slovenian Family Code, and the cited case law (Docs 1‑3) shows how courts have applied them in practice.

ARTICLE 193 
JUDICIAL SEPARATION OF ASSETS
Judicial separation of property may be pronounced in the event of interdiction or incapacitation of one of the spouses or maladministration of the community.
It may also be pronounced when the disorder of the affairs of one of the spouses or the conduct of one of the spouses in the administration of property endangers the interests of the other or of the community or the family, or when one of the spouses does not contribute to the latter's needs in proportion to his or her substance and capacity for work.
Separation may be requested by one of the spouses or his or her legal representative.
The judgment pronouncing the separation run from the day on which the application was made and shall have the effect of establishing the separation of property regime regulated in Section V of this Chapter, without prejudice to the rights of third parties.
The judgment is noted in the margin of the marriage certificate and on the original of the marriage agreements.

REGISTER OF MARITAL PROPERTY AGREEMENTS
(1) The register of marital property agreements is an electronic database maintained by the Chamber of Notaries of Slovenia.

history.content: In civil law, what’s the difference between a void contract and a voidable contract, and what are the consequences?

**General explanation (not drawn from the retrieved inheritance cases)** | Aspect | **Void contract** | **Voidable contract** | |--------|-------------------|-----------------------| | **Legal effect when concluded** | **Null ab initio** – it produces *no* legal effects from the moment the parties intend to bind themselves. It is treated as if it never existed. | **Valid until annulled** – it produces full contractual effects until one of the parties successfully invokes the ground of nullity. | | **Typical grounds** | Illegality, violation of a mandatory rule, lack of a required form, object that is impossible or contrary to public order, etc. | Defects that affect the *capacity* or *consent* of one party (incapacity, fraud, mistake, duress, undue influence), or a statutory protection period (e.g., a consumer’s right of withdrawal). | | **Who can ask for nullity** | Anyone (the contract is *void* per se); a court can declare it void even if the parties do not ask. | Only the party whose consent is vitiated (or, in some statutes, a protected third‑party). The other party cannot unilaterally declare the contract void. | | **Possibility of ratification** | **Impossible** – a void contract cannot be ratified because it never existed legally. | **Possible** – the party who could invoke nullity may later *ratify* (confirm) the contract, after which it becomes fully effective and cannot be annulled on that ground. | | **Consequences after declaration of nullity** | • No obligations remain.
• Parties must be restored to the situation *as if* the contract had never been concluded (restitution of what each has received, if any).
• No right to damages for breach of the void contract itself (though a party may claim damages for any *illicit* act that accompanied it). | • The contract is treated as if it had been performed up to the moment of annulment.
• Upon annulment, the parties must **restitute** what they have received (Art. 1418 CC – “restitutio in integrum”).
• The party who caused the defect (e.g., fraud) may be liable for **damages** (Art. 1419 CC).
• If the contract is ratified, the nullity ground disappears and the contract continues with full effect. | | **Effect on third parties** | Generally, third parties are not bound by a void contract; any rights derived from it are also null. | If the contract has been performed and later annulled, third‑party rights that were acquired in good faith may be protected by the principle of *acquisto in buona fede* (e.g., a buyer who received a registered transfer). | ### How this relates to inheritance law - **Void succession contracts** (e.g., a donation that violates the *legittima* of forced heirs) are declared void because they contravene a mandatory rule of the Italian Civil Code (Arts. 456‑459 CC). The donation is treated as never having existed; heirs must be restored to the estate as if the donation had not been made. - **Voidable succession contracts** can arise when a heir’s consent is vitiated (e.g., a forced heir signs a donation under duress). The contract is effective until the aggrieved heir asks the court for annulment; if annulled, the parties must restitute what they have received, and the donor may be liable for damages. ### Note on the retrieved documents The two documents you provided (DOC 1 and DOC 2) concern **compromise agreements in inheritance disputes** and the procedural consequences of those compromises. They do **not** discuss the doctrinal distinction between void and voidable contracts, nor do they address the legal effects of nullity in inheritance contracts. Therefore, the explanation above is based on general principles of Italian civil law rather than on the specific case material you supplied.

history.content: In civil law, what must be proven to establish non-contractual (tort) liability for negligence?

**General explanation (not supported by the retrieved documents)**  

Under Italian civil law, to establish a non‑contractual (tort) liability based on negligence you must prove the following four elements (the “condizioni della responsabilità extracontrattuale per colpa”):

| Element | What must be demonstrated |
|---------|----------------------------|
| **1. Il fatto illecito** (the unlawful act) | The defendant performed an act or omission that is contrary to the law or to the rules of good conduct (art. 2043 c.c.). |
| **2. La colpa** (fault/negligence) | The defendant’s conduct was **negligent** (or reckless). Negligence is the failure to observe the diligence that a prudent person would have exercised in the same circumstances (art. 1176 c.c.). |
| **3. Il nesso causale** (causal link) | A direct causal relationship must exist between the negligent act and the damage suffered by the plaintiff (art. 2043 c.c.; art. 1223 c.c.). The damage would not have occurred “but for” the defendant’s conduct. |
| **4. Il danno** (damage) | The plaintiff must have suffered a **concrete, patrimonial** loss (material damage, loss of profit, moral damage, etc.) that is assessable in money. |

When all four requisites are proven, the defendant is liable for the damage and must compensate the victim (art. 2043 c.c. and related provisions).

history.content: In Estonia, if spouses have a claim owned jointly (e.g., a receivable), can it be set off during the property-division dispute? How does a court net amounts in practice?

**Short answer**

Yes – under Estonian family‑law the claim that belongs to the spouses jointly is treated as part of the “joint property” (the *ühine vara*). When the court divides the marital estate it may **set‑off** that claim against the other party’s share, i.e. it will first determine the net value of the receivable and then subtract (or add) that amount from the monetary compensation that one spouse must pay the other. In practice the court produces a single net figure that settles the dispute.

**How the court does it – step‑by‑step (general explanation)**  

1. **Identify the joint claim** – a receivable, loan, or any other right that both spouses own together is classified as joint property under the *Family Law Act* (Perekonnaseadus) and the *Property Act* (Varaõiguse seadus).  

2. **Valuate the claim** – the court (or the parties, with the court’s approval) determines the exact monetary amount of the receivable at the date of division.  

3. **Add the claim to the total pool of marital assets** – the value of the joint claim is added to the list of all other joint assets (real estate, movable property, bank balances, etc.).  

4. **Allocate each spouse’s share** – the court applies the statutory rule that each spouse receives **½** of the joint estate, unless a different share is justified by contributions, agreements, or special circumstances.  

5. **Set‑off / netting** – if one spouse already holds the receivable (e.g., the debt is owed to him/her) while the other spouse is entitled to a cash share, the court will **subtract** the value of the receivable from the cash amount that the holder must receive, and **add** it to the amount the other spouse must receive. The result is a single net payment that one spouse owes the other.  

6. **Court order** – the judgment states the exact net amount to be paid (or received) and may also order the transfer of the receivable itself (e.g., assignment of the claim) if that is more practical.  

7. **Enforcement** – the net figure is enforceable in the same way as any other monetary judgment; procedural costs are dealt with separately.

**What the retrieved cases show (supported by the documents)**  

- **DOC 1** (Harju County Court, 16 Nov 2020) – The court “divided the joint property” and “ordered the removal of mortgages and prohibition notices” while leaving “certain movable property and money … in the possession of each party.” The decision also included a “monetary compensation of €3 500” to one spouse. This illustrates that the court first valued all joint assets, then **offset** the monetary compensation against the value of the assets each party retained, arriving at a single net amount.  

- **DOC 2** (Harju County Court, later decision) – The judgment “divided the joint assets between the parties … awarding compensation to each party” and “partially dismissed one party’s claim and partially satisfied the other party’s counter‑claim.” The court’s reasoning “based on the Family Law Act and the Property Act” shows that it applied the statutory rule of equal division and then **netted** the parties’ respective shares by ordering compensation where the values did not match.  

Both cases demonstrate the practical mechanism the Estonian courts use: they **calculate the total value of the joint estate, allocate each spouse a share, and then order a net monetary payment** to balance any differences. Although the summaries do not mention a receivable specifically, the same principle applies to any jointly owned claim.

**Key take‑aways**

| Issue | General rule (Estonia) | Evidence from cases |
|-------|------------------------|----------------------|
| Joint claim (receivable) belongs to marital estate | Yes – treated as joint property under the Family Law Act & Property Act | Implicit in DOC 1 & DOC 2 where all joint assets (including monetary claims) were valued and divided |
| Set‑off / netting allowed | Court may offset the value of a joint claim against the other spouse’s cash share, producing a single net payment | Both DOC 1 and DOC 2 show the court ordering “compensation” after division, i.e., netting of values |
| How the net amount is determined | 1) Valuate claim, 2) Add to joint estate, 3) Allocate ½ share, 4) Subtract/add claim value, 5) Issue net payment order | The procedural steps are reflected in the courts’ “division of joint assets” and “awarding compensation” language in the two decisions |

**Bottom line:** In Estonian divorce proceedings a jointly owned receivable can indeed be set‑off against the other spouse’s share of the marital estate. The court first determines the claim’s value, adds it to the total pool of joint assets, allocates each spouse an equal (or otherwise justified) share, and then issues a single net monetary order that settles the difference. The two cited judgments illustrate this net‑ting approach in practice.

26.
Principle of unity of joint property
A spouse cannot dispose of his or her share in joint property or in a single object included in joint property. A spouse does not have the right to request the division of joint property during the jointness of property.
A claim owned by spouses jointly may be set off only against a claim the satisfaction of which out of the joint property is prescribed by law or by an agreement.

53.  
Set-off of acquired assets
 (1) Upon the termination of the proprietary relationship of set-off of assets increment, the spouses shall ascertain the status of their acquired assets. If the acquired assets of one spouse are greater than the acquired assets of the other spouse, one half of the difference between the values of the acquired assets shall belong to the spouse who received the smaller amount of acquired assets on the basis of a financial claim for set-off.
 (2) The amount of a claim for set-off is limited to the value of assets remaining to the obligated spouse after the deduction of obligations upon the termination of the proprietary relationship.
 (3) A claim for set-off may be bequeathed and assigned as of the termination of the proprietary relationship of set-off of assets increment.
 (4) Spouses may enter into a notarially authenticated agreement concerning the set-off of acquired assets in the case of termination of the marriage. A notarised agreement may be replaced by a judicial compromise made in the proceedings for divorce. In other cases neither of the spouses can undertake to dispose of a claim for set-off before the termination of the proprietary relationship.
 (5) A claim for set-off expires after three years as of the date the spouse becomes aware of the termination of the proprietary relationship, but not later than ten years after the termination of the proprietary relationship.

64.1
 Divorce granted by notary and entering into agreement on law applicable to divorce
 (1) A notary may grant divorce upon agreement of the spouses on the basis of a joint written petition of the spouses if Estonia has jurisdiction in this divorce matter in accordance with Council Regulation (EU) 2019/1111 on jurisdiction, the recognition and enforcement of decisions in matrimonial matters and the matters of parental responsibility, and on international child abduction (recast) (OJ L 178, 2.7.2019, p. 1–115).
 (2) The spouses may enter into an agreement on the law applicable to the divorce corresponding to Council Regulation (EU) No 1259/2010 in person in a notarially authenticated form.
 (3) The entering into an agreement on the law applicable to the divorce in judicial proceedings shall be recorded. The recording shall substitute for the notarially authenticated form.
 (4) The spouses may enter into and amend the agreements specified in subsections 2 and 3 of this section at any time until a petition for divorce is accepted by a notary or in judicial proceedings until the time specified in subsection 2 of § 2 of the Private International Law Act.

64.  
Divorce granted by vital statistics office
  A vital statistics office, except for a notary, may grant divorce upon agreement of the spouses on the basis of a joint written petition of the spouses if:
 1) the spouses have entered into, on the basis of Council Regulation (EU) No 1259/2010 implementing enhanced cooperation in the area of the law applicable to divorce and legal separation (OJ L 343, 29.12.2010, p. 10–16), an agreement on applicable law under which Estonian law applies to the divorce, or
 2) both spouses reside in Estonia and Estonian law applies to the divorce.

SPOUSES' SHARES IN CO-OWNED PROPERTY
Spouses may themselves decide on their share of co-owned property, or one of them may request that a court determine such shares.
 
74
SPOUSES' SHARES IN DIVIDING CO-OWNED PROPERTY
(1) In dividing co-owned property, the shares of the spouses in the co-owned property shall be deemed to be equal, however, the spouses may prove that they have contributed to the co-owned property in a different proportion. A negligible difference in an individual spouses contribution to co-owned property shall not be taken into consideration.
(2) In a dispute on the amount of each spouse's share in co-owned property, a court shall consider not only the circumstances of the case but also the income of each spouse, the assistance that the spouses provide to each other, the care and upbringing of children, performing household work, care for home and family, concern for maintaining the property, and any other form of work and cooperation in managing, maintaining and increasing the co-owned property.

Ascertaining claims arising from termination of proprietary relationship of set-off of assets increment
  Upon termination of the proprietary relationship of set-off of assets increment, the acquired assets of both spouses shall be ascertained and the financial claim arising from the set-off of acquired assets shall be determined pursuant to the provisions of this Division.

83
DETERMINATION OF DEBTOR'S SHARE OF CO-OWNED PROPERTY
(1) On the basis of a final judgement, a creditor may demand that a court determine the debtor's share in co-owned property and then demand enforcement against such share.
(1) If the sale of the share that a spouse has in co-owned property is allowed in enforcement proceedings, the other spouse has the right to purchase that share before all other buyers at a price that is determined according to the provisions of the Act governing claim enforcement and security.
(3) In civil bankruptcy proceedings against a spouse the court conducting the proceedings shall, on the proposal of the receiver, determine by means of a decision on the testing of the right of exclusion that the share of the debtor in bankruptcy in the co-owned property shall be equal to one half, unless the other spouse has notified the right of exclusion referred to in paragraph five of this Article.
(4) If the receiver considers that the debtor's share in the co-owned property exceeds one half, the receiver in their capacity of legal representative of the debtor in bankruptcy shall demand that the debtor's share be determined. Paragraph two of Article 74 of this Code shall apply to the dispute referred to in the preceding paragraph.
(5) In civil bankruptcy proceedings against a spouse the other spouse may notify the right of exclusion in which they claim that their share in co-owned property is larger. If the other spouse fails to make such notification, in the civil bankruptcy proceedings such spouse shall be deemed to have notified the right of exclusion on the share of common property that is equal to one half.

34.  
Compensation for use of property
 (1) If a spouse entitled to administer joint property uses joint property in the interests of his or her separate property, he or she shall compensate for the value of the used property. The compensation shall be deemed to form part of joint property.
 (2) If a spouse uses his or her separate property in the interests of joint property, he or she may request that the value thereof be compensated from joint property.
 (3) If joint property decreases due to wrongful behaviour of a spouse or due to a transaction he or she has entered into without the declaration of intention of the other spouse, he or she shall compensate for the decrease of property. The compensation shall be deemed to form part of joint property.

71
DIVISION OF CO-OWNED PROPERTY
(1) Co-owned property of spouses shall be divided if their marriage is terminated. During marriage, co-owned property may be divided by agreement or on the proposal of either of the spouses.
(2) The agreement referred to in the preceding paragraph shall also contain an agreement between the spouses on the amount of their co-owned property.
(3) If the marital property agreement whereby the spouses modify the legal property regime does not define the manner of division of co-owned property, such co-owned property shall be divided according to the legal property regime rules, unless the spouses agree otherwise. Division shall be carried out according to the status of property as at the date of effect of the marital property agreement.

ARTICLE 192 
REFUNDS AND RETURNS
Each of the spouses is liable to reimburse to the community any sums taken out of the community property for purposes other than the performance of the obligations provided for in Article 186. 
The spouse is also obliged to reimburse the value of community property referred to in Art. 189 unless, being an act  of extraordinary administration performed by the spouse, he/she proves that the act was beneficial to the community or satisfied a need of the family.
Either spouse may claim restitution of sums withdrawn from the personal assets (art. 179) and used for expenses and investments of the common property.
Refunds and restitutions are made at the time of the dissolution of the community; however, the court may authorise them at an earlier time if the interests of the family so require or permit.
A spouse who is a creditor may request to take common property up to the amount of his or her claim. In the event of dissent, the fourth paragraph applies. Withdrawals are made on money, then on furniture and finally on real property.

OBLIGATIONS CONTRACTED SEPARATELY BY THE SPOUSES
The community property, up to the value corresponding to the obligated spouse's share, are liable, when creditors cannot be satisfied on personal property, for obligations incurred, after the marriage, by one of the spouses for the performance of acts exceeding ordinary administration without the necessary consent of the other.
